Issues.Title: bug with System.Linq.Dynamic.Core library, code shutdown if linker is enable
Issues.Body:
Hello guys, im facing a really strange behavior with the usage of System.Linq.Dynamic.Core library.
On webassembly mode, with linker enabled (defaut behavior), the code shutdown when a method of this library is used (no exception, no error in the console, just the code stop when this library  is called).

If i disable the linker, back to normal, but my app make 2 minute to be ready wich is not acceptable.

I try to play with Linker.xml as documented here https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/host-and-deploy/blazor/configure-linker?view=aspnetcore-3.1 but when i use it i have this exception in the browser console "Default constructor not found for type Is.Geckos.Blazor.Client.App", with App.razor the entry point of my app.

I try to add in the linker.xml
````
<assembly fullname="System.Linq.Dynamic.Core" /> //the problematic dll
<assembly fullname="Is.Geckos.Blazor.Client" /> // my blazor app, i don't know if i have to add in the linker it's not really clear
````
but no effect, even if i put nothing in the <linker> node i have this error at startup.

So i don't know what really do now, it's a black box for me.

I take all your suggestions !

PS : i have to put at least 100 console.writeline to debug this problem, my app is really huge there is million of line of code. We really need a better support for webassembly. It's not the first time i see strange behavior in webassembly and was such a pain to debug. im suppose to deploy my app in webassembly in production in few month (i develop in server-side) but i'm more and more worried about this mode. Hope you will make the thing better for the future.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug with System.Linq.Dynamic.Core library, code shutdown if linker is enable" (#18741)

Issues.Title: Blazor server looses connection in mobile web browser almost instantly when minimizing app.
Issues.Body:

### Describe the bug
Blazor server looses connection in iOS mobile web browsers, making it impossible to use in production scenarious like "Please enter code we sent you via SMS". We are experiencing this right now, users are stuck without possibility to enter code, because blazor server shows "Attemting to reconnect", which forces users to press "Reload" after failed attempts to reconnect, which makes blazor server force to send new sms, which users could not read (it will produce another broken connection in 1 second after going to sms app instead of browser) etc etc

### To Reproduce
Create any tutorial blazor server app, upload to hosting, visit through iOS mobile web browser.

Got Exceptions? Include both the message and the stack trace

Issues.Title: Use typeof() rather than caching Type in static
Issues.Body:
From https://github.com/dotnet/corert/pull/7962/files#r373850627

> It would be better to deleted these and convert the few places that use it to use `typeof`, e.g. `if (type == typeof(Decimal))`.
> 
> Caching these in statics is actually a deoptimization.
> 
> The JIT has optimization for `operator==` on System.Type that kicks in when one of the sides is typeof. It should compile this into a simple vtable compare.

/cc @jkotas
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Use typeof() rather than caching Type in static" (#18737)

Issues.Title: The specified CGI application encountered an error and the server terminated the process.
Issues.Body:
I have an ASP.NET core 2.2 application hosted on Azure, and I encountered today an error:
The specified CGI application encountered an error and the server terminated the process.

Looking at the logs, I saw the exception details. It was a service that calls an async method in the Dispose() method, and the async method threw System.Data.SqlClient.SqlException: Timeout expired. 

Since this error occurred "outside of a context", it was not caught by any middleware or parts of the framework and the application was terminated. This is a bug in my code that is easy to fix. 

All the above is understandable and fine.

The exception was in the logs one time and the AspNetCore Module or HttpPlatformHandler didn't attempt to restart the process again. As a result, the application was down for about an hour until I manually restarted it

The rapidFailuresPerMinute setting is not set, so it should have a default value of 10. However, it seems the actual behaviour is one failure and application is down until restarted.

I do understand that it is a bug on my side that ultimately caused the crash, but such bugs can happen. It would be nice if the Framework logs the error then recovers.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "The specified CGI application encountered an error and the server terminated the process." (#18735)

Issues.Title: Authentication Identity Says no Email Service Configured While it Uses the Email Service Configured
Issues.Body:
### Describe the bug
I've followed the steps in the documentation to add authentication. Tried doing it to an app I already have built but failed and the docs only explain how to add authentication on a new one. So I created a new one, exactly as described in the docs. Email service has been hit or miss.

Email service was working, intermittently meaning one day it worked once by sending out an email then stopped sending out email when there were no code changes, next day it would send out no email though the email service code was being called and there were no code changes. Day after that it was back to sending out email again, still no code changes. Hoped all would be fine but now if I try to register a user as described in the docs, step by step, I'm told that the app has no real email sender registered so I can click the link to confirm which is what you experience before you add the email service as directed in docs. Yet the code within `EmailSender.cs` is hit, it succeeds and there's no error or exception. In fact the screenshot below shows the email activity from the SendGrid dashboard as sent and processed. The email is actually never received though because, another issue, sending to Hotmail doesn't work, the email doesn't show up in any folder, no junk, no nothing. Well I received the first email I ever sent one time, since then Hotmail has received no further emails from SendGrid, Gmail has no problem at all and has received all that were processed and sent. So the code does work yet the Identity library seems to have lost touch with itself and thinks there's no email service when it's actually using it. 

I'll include a link to the repo I just put on GitHub so the entire codebase I'm using can be viewed. I haven't modified the code or steps within the documentation at all. Just been spending days testing emails because it seems to work then not work. And then Hotmail accounts don't receive email at all from SendGrid which is the service that the documentation suggests that we use. I could just create another app since I've not made any changes of my own but if I'm getting issues this heavily on boilerplate then I don't think another copy would be a solution.

![SendGrid Activity - Email Sent to Hotmail Account](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16159685/73597067-4a744980-44f6-11ea-811b-c020ec567c80.png)

### To Reproduce
- Account confirmation and password recovery in ASP.NET Core
[Authentication Asp.Net Core 3.1 Documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/security/authentication/accconfirm?view=aspnetcore-3.1&tabs=visual-studio)
Haven't gone past test password reset emails working because the confirm account email section is working half of the time and now the app thinks there isn't one, below is the stopping point in the docs.
[Register, confirm email, and reset password section](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/security/authentication/accconfirm?view=aspnetcore-3.1&tabs=visual-studio#register-confirm-email-and-reset-password)

[GitHub Repo](https://github.com/DanJ210/LoginAccounts)

Steps to reproduce for me were following the documentation with the links provided right above and registering users to go through the confirm email flow which has worked before. I made no code changes or additions so I couldn't described what could have happened to cause it not to detect the email service while it uses the email service and sends out an email that Hotmail no longer receives.

Issues.Title: OpenIdConnectHandler: doesn't use updated user data from userInformationReceivedContext
Issues.Body:
### Describe the bug
Using OnUserInformationReceived event to override user information claims, after updating the user JsonElement provided in the context it's expected to be reflected in the issued identity.
After digging into the source code (https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/blob/master/src/Security/Authentication/OpenIdConnect/src/OpenIdConnectHandler.cs) i could see that the updated data element is ignored therefor not updated.

### To Reproduce
Use OnUserInformationReceived events to update the context.User data element with new/updated claim values.
Example: Add another claim type "sub" to context.User and make sure it's included in 
Options.ClaimsAction as DeleteClaimAction

- Expected: New user data to be used for running the ClaimActions on.
- Actual: New user data is ignored and "sub" claim is included.

### Source code to be updated

from
```
 foreach (var action in Options.ClaimActions)
  {
        action.Run(user.RootElement, identity, ClaimsIssuer);
  }
```
to
```
 foreach (var action in Options.ClaimActions)
  {
        action.Run(updatedUser.RootElement, identity, ClaimsIssuer);
  }
```

### Further technical details
- ASP.NET Core version
3.1.1
- Include the output of `dotnet --info`

 Commit:    cd82f021f4

Issues.Title: DefaultAuthorizationHandlerProvider always requires all authorization handlers
Issues.Body:
In some of our projects we use the requirement policy approach to cut off requests based on request specific constraints. This could be fine grained authorization towards a resource. Such custom authorisation handler has for instance a service dependency, which has a database dependency.

Typically you add the authorization attribute as global filter to your API controllers. Some controller actions might have the AllowAnonymous attribute. Now for all authorization required controller actions, the pipeline will resolve all authorization handlers, for every request. If you have lots of authorization handlers (requirements) which have dependencies, the system creates DI overhead.

I have illustrated the case with this web project. See the TestCaseSetup class for more information:
[FooWeb.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/files/4142519/FooWeb.zip)

The challenge is the DefaultAuthorizationHandlerProvider. This wants all registered AuthorizationHandler instances in it's constructor. Later on all handlers will be invoked and they have to check for themselves if they handle a Requirement. 

This mechanism works fine when the authorization handlers are registered as Singleton. As soon as you use DI for scoped services, the system adds overhead. You could also have side effects, because you might not realize all handlers are resolved on each request. Maybe you depend on a tenant specific context in one of the handlers which can't be resolved in all controller action types. Since all handlers are resolved, you request might unexpectedly fail due to this.

Replacing the DefaultAuthorizationHandlerProvider doesn't seem like a good option, since you would like to have some Requirement <--> AuthorizationHandler mapping, I guess. Making the provider resolve handlers smarter implies you add runtime cost to every request as well.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "DefaultAuthorizationHandlerProvider always requires all authorization handlers" (#18728)

Issues.Title: Synchronous call inside XDocument.LoadAsync causes --> System.InvalidOperationException: Synchronous operations are disallowed
Issues.Body:
<!--

More information on our issue management policies can be found here: https://aka.ms/aspnet/issue-policies

Please keep in mind that the GitHub issue tracker is not intended as a general support forum, but for reporting non-security bugs and feature requests.

If you believe you have an issue that affects the SECURITY of the platform, please do NOT create an issue and instead email your issue details to secure@microsoft.com. Your report may be eligible for our [bug bounty](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/msrc/bounty-dot-net-core) but ONLY if it is reported through email.
For other types of questions, consider using [StackOverflow](https://stackoverflow.com).

-->

### Synchronous operations are disallowed (kestrel) when calling XDocument.LoadAsync
When a .net core 3.1 ASP.Net WebApi receives an xml input and tries to load that into an Xdoc using the XDocument.LoadAsync method, the web api throws Synchronous operations are disallowed error and the stack trace points to a synchronous call from inside XDocument.LoadAsync method. 

Notice in the stack trace 4 calls down from System.Xml.Linq.XDocument.LoadAsync there is a System.Xml.Linq.XContainer.ContentReader.ReadContentFrom which inturn makes calls to ystem.Xml.XmlTextReaderImpl.ReadData(). Due to this, the web server throws ystem.InvalidOperationException: Synchronous operations are disallowed. 

### To Reproduce
1. Clone the linked GitHub repo --> [NetCoreUpgrade](https://github.com/mayur-rao/NetCoreUpgrade.git)
2. docker-compose up -d to launch the web api with docker.
3. Open the solution with Visual Studio 2019.
4. Set start up project to WebApiHitter
5. Launch the netcore app. 
6. After processing few requests, the web api will throw an error : 

Link to github repo [here](https://github.com/mayur-rao/NetCoreUpgrade)

``` C#
			var xmlRequest = context.HttpContext.Request;
			using (var xmlStream = new StreamReader(xmlRequest.Body))
			{
				var xmlDoc = await XDocument.LoadAsync(xmlStream, LoadOptions.None, CancellationToken.None);
				return await InputFormatterResult.SuccessAsync(xmlDoc);
```
above file available [here](https://github.com/mayur-rao/NetCoreUpgrade/blob/master/XmlBasedWebApp/Formatter/XmlInputFormatter.cs)

```An unhandled exception has occurred while executing the request.
System.InvalidOperationException: Synchronous operations are disallowed. Call ReadAsync or set AllowSynchronousIO to true instead.
   at Microsoft.AspNetCore.Server.Kestrel.Core.Internal.Http.HttpRequestStream.Read(Byte[] buffer, Int32 offset, Int32 count)
   at System.IO.StreamReader.ReadBuffer(Span`1 userBuffer, Boolean& readToUserBuffer)
   at System.IO.StreamReader.ReadSpan(Span`1 buffer)
   at System.IO.StreamReader.Read(Char[] buffer, Int32 index, Int32 count)
   at System.Xml.XmlTextReaderImpl.ReadData()
   at System.Xml.XmlTextReaderImpl.ParseText(Int32& startPos, Int32& endPos, Int32& outOrChars)
   at System.Xml.XmlTextReaderImpl.FinishPartialValue()
   at System.Xml.XmlTextReaderImpl.get_Value()
   at System.Xml.Linq.XContainer.ContentReader.ReadContentFrom(XContainer rootContainer, XmlReader r)
   at System.Xml.Linq.XContainer.ReadContentFromAsync(XmlReader r, CancellationToken cancellationToken)
   at System.Xml.Linq.XContainer.ReadContentFromAsync(XmlReader r, LoadOptions o, CancellationToken cancellationToken)
   at System.Xml.Linq.XDocument.LoadAsyncInternal(XmlReader reader, LoadOptions options, CancellationToken cancellationToken)
   at System.Xml.Linq.XDocument.LoadAsync(TextReader textReader, LoadOptions options, CancellationToken cancellationToken)
   at XmlBasedWebApp.Formatter.XmlInputFormatter.ReadRequestBodyAsync(InputFormatterContext context) in /src/XmlBasedWebApp/Formatter/XmlInputFormatter.cs:line 23
   at Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.ModelBinding.Binders.BodyModelBinder.BindModelAsync(ModelBindingContext bindingContext)
   at Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.ModelBinding.ParameterBinder.BindModelAsync(ActionContext actionContext, IModelBinder modelBinder, IValueProvider valueProvider, ParameterDescriptor parameter, ModelMetadata metadata, Object value)
   at Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Controllers.ControllerBinderDelegateProvider.<>c__DisplayClass0_0.<<CreateBinderDelegate>g__Bind|0>d.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Infrastructure.ControllerActionInvoker.<InvokeInnerFilterAsync>g__Awaited|13_0(ControllerActionInvoker invoker, Task lastTask, State next, Scope scope, Object state, Boolean isCompleted)
   at Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Infrastructure.ResourceInvoker.<InvokeFilterPipelineAsync>g__Awaited|19_0(ResourceInvoker invoker, Task lastTask, State next, Scope scope, Object state, Boolean isCompleted)
   at Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Infrastructure.ResourceInvoker.<InvokeAsync>g__Awaited|17_0(ResourceInvoker invoker, Task task, IDisposable scope)
   at Microsoft.AspNetCore.Routing.EndpointMiddleware.<Invoke>g__AwaitRequestTask|6_0(Endpoint endpoint, Task requestTask, ILogger logger)
   at Microsoft.AspNetCore.Authorization.AuthorizationMiddleware.Invoke(HttpContext context)
   at Microsoft.AspNetCore.Diagnostics.DeveloperExceptionPageMiddleware.Invoke(HttpContext context)
```

Further technical details
- ASP.NET Core version is 3.1.1
```dotnet --info
.NET Core SDK (reflecting any global.json):
 Version:   3.1.101
 Commit:    b377529961

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     Windows
 OS Version:  10.0.14393
 OS Platform: Windows
 RID:         win10-x64
 Base Path:   C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\3.1.101\

Host (useful for support):
  Version: 3.1.1
  Commit:  a1388f194c
```
- I have run this project on VS 2019 - Version 16.4.4

Issues.Title: KnownFrameworkReference workarounds not working for certain AspNetCore-Tooling tests
Issues.Body:
We attempt to update our FrameworkReference to Microsoft.NetCore.App so that we reference the shared framework version from versions.props, rather than the version in the SDK:

https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore-tooling/blob/9a05bd16c6f075f90ae2fe7ae0b9ab03199eb9b6/Directory.Build.targets#L18-L28

However, for certain AspNetCore-Tooling tests, this isn't happening for some reason, which is causing the tests to fail any time dotnet/runtime changes API surface area. This has happened a couple times, most recently in https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore-tooling/pull/1551, and the solution is typically to wait until we can get a new SDK. We should figure out why the workaround doesn't apply to these tests, and fix it:

```
MSB4018: The "RazorTagHelper" task failed unexpectedly. 
[F:\workspace\_work\1\s\artifacts\tmp\Release\Razor\txwy4p0j.jou\ClassLibrary\ClassLibrary.csproj]\r\nF:\workspace\_work\1\s\src\Razor\src\Microsoft.NET.Sdk.Razor\build\netstandard2.0\Microsoft.NET.Sdk.Razor.CodeGeneration.targets(99,5): error MSB4018: System.TypeLoadException: Could not load type 'System.Diagnostics.Debugger' from assembly 'System.Runtime, Version=5.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b03f5f7f11d50a3a'. 
[F:\workspace\_work\1\s\artifacts\tmp\Release\Razor\txwy4p0j.jou\ClassLibrary\ClassLibrary.csproj]\r\nF:\workspace\_work\1\s\src\Razor\src\Microsoft.NET.Sdk.Razor\build\netstandard2.0\Microsoft.NET.Sdk.Razor.CodeGeneration.targets(99,5): error MSB4018: at Microsoft.AspNetCore.Razor.Tasks.DotNetToolTask.Execute() 
[F:\workspace\_work\1\s\artifacts\tmp\Release\Razor\txwy4p0j.jou\ClassLibrary\ClassLibrary.csproj]\r\nF:\workspace\_work\1\s\src\Razor\src\Microsoft.NET.Sdk.Razor\build\netstandard2.0\Microsoft.NET.Sdk.Razor.CodeGeneration.targets(99,5): error MSB4018: at Microsoft.Build.BackEnd.TaskExecutionHost.Microsoft.Build.BackEnd.ITaskExecutionHost.Execute() 
[F:\workspace\_work\1\s\artifacts\tmp\Release\Razor\txwy4p0j.jou\ClassLibrary\ClassLibrary.csproj]\r\nF:\workspace\_work\1\s\src\Razor\src\Microsoft.NET.Sdk.Razor\build\netstandard2.0\Microsoft.NET.Sdk.Razor.CodeGeneration.targets(99,5): error MSB4018: at Microsoft.Build.BackEnd.TaskBuilder.ExecuteInstantiatedTask(ITaskExecutionHost taskExecutionHost, TaskLoggingContext taskLoggingContext, TaskHost taskHost, ItemBucket bucket, TaskExecutionMode howToExecuteTask) 
[F:\workspace\_work\1\s\artifacts\tmp\Release\Razor\txwy4p0j.jou\ClassLibrary\ClassLib
```

https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore-tooling/tree/master/src/Razor/test/testapps/ClassLibrary

This could be similar to our template tests - since these are executing from the artifacts dir, maybe they're not importing our directory.build.targets file. Or, maybe it's related to these tests using the Razor SDK.

CC @dotnet/aspnet-build @Tratcher

Issues.Title: Adding Newtonsoft.Json Support for SignalR Client-Side Requires Unspecified Work
Issues.Body:
<!--

More information on our issue management policies can be found here: https://aka.ms/aspnet/issue-policies

Please keep in mind that the GitHub issue tracker is not intended as a general support forum, but for reporting non-security bugs and feature requests.

If you believe you have an issue that affects the SECURITY of the platform, please do NOT create an issue and instead email your issue details to secure@microsoft.com. Your report may be eligible for our [bug bounty](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/msrc/bounty-dot-net-core) but ONLY if it is reported through email.
For other types of questions, consider using [StackOverflow](https://stackoverflow.com).

-->
### Technical Details
I'm working with ASP.NET Core 3.1.1 and I'm working in a hosted Blazor WebAssembly project using version 3.2.0-preview1.20073.1 of that. The client SignalR package I'm using is up-to-date (3.1.1).

### Describe the bug
As described [here](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/migration/22-to-30?view=aspnetcore-3.1&tabs=visual-studio#use-newtonsoftjson-in-an-aspnet-core-30-signalr-project), SignalR by default is using System.Text.Json for serialization, but you can still opt to use Newtonsoft.Json. The instructions include using an extension method in Startup.cs on the server side and where the hub connection is built on the client side. When I followed these instructions I got the following error:
`WASM: System.InvalidOperationException: A suitable constructor for type 'Microsoft.AspNetCore.SignalR.Protocol.NewtonsoftJsonHubProtocol' could not be located. Ensure the type is concrete and services are registered for all parameters of a public constructor.`
After taking a peek at source code, I resolved the issue by adding `builder.Services.AddSingleton<IHubProtocol, NewtonsoftJsonHubProtocol>(sp => new NewtonsoftJsonHubProtocol());` to Program.cs on the client side. My Program.cs looks like this:
```
using System.Threading.Tasks;
using Microsoft.AspNetCore.Blazor.Hosting;
using Microsoft.AspNetCore.SignalR.Protocol;
using Microsoft.Extensions.DependencyInjection;

namespace BlazorTestApp.Client
{
	public class Program
	{
		public static async Task Main(string[] args)
		{
			var builder = WebAssemblyHostBuilder.CreateDefault(args);
			builder.RootComponents.Add<App>("app");
			builder.Services.AddSingleton<IHubProtocol, NewtonsoftJsonHubProtocol>(sp => new NewtonsoftJsonHubProtocol());

			await builder.Build().RunAsync();
		}
	}
}
```

I'm not sure if this is an issue in other ASP.NET Core apps, or just Blazor WebAssembly. It seems like, unless I missed something or am doing something wrong, either the AddNewtonsoftJsonProtocol() extension method isn't working correctly, or the documentation needs to be updated.

### To Reproduce
<!--
What steps can we follow to reproduce the issue?

We  code! Include a complete code listing or point us to a minimalistic GitHub repo.

``` C#
Console.WriteLine("Hello, World!");
```

Got Exceptions? Include both the message and the stack trace
-->
Follow the instructions [here](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/aspnet/blazor-webassembly-3-2-0-preview-1-release-now-available/) under the "Support for the .NET SignalR Client" section. Next, follow the instructions [here](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/migration/22-to-30?view=aspnetcore-3.1&tabs=visual-studio#use-newtonsoftjson-in-an-aspnet-core-30-signalr-project) to use Newtonsoft.Json. Simply run the app and you should see the error in the browser console.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Adding Newtonsoft.Json Support for SignalR Client-Side Requires Unspecified Work" (#18721)

Issues.Title: Blazor WebAssembly release-published app still tries to load a .pdb
Issues.Body:
I don't know why, but for hosted apps (maybe standalone too if you reference some other class library, didn't check), after publishing in release mode it still tries to fetch `MyApp.Shared.pdb` at runtime, causing the server to return a 404. It correctly does *not* try to fetch `MyApp.Client.pdb`, so I don't know why it does try to fetch `MyApp.Shared.pdb`.

This is problematic because:

 * It's an unnecessary HTTP request
 * It's distracting to see what appears to be an error in the dev tools

Also, the build output places `MyApp.Shared.pdb` in `_framework\_bin` on disk, even though the web server is (correctly) configured not to serve it.

Looks like something is mistaken in our publish process. In release builds, there should be no `.pdb` files emitted to the publish output, and none referenced from `blazor.boot.json`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Blazor WebAssembly release-published app still tries to load a .pdb" (#18712)

Issues.Title: [SignalR] Set "UntrustedData" security mode in MessagePackSerializerOptions
Issues.Body:
In response to [CVE-2020-5234](https://github.com/neuecc/MessagePack-CSharp/security/advisories/GHSA-7q36-4xx7-xcxf) we should turn on the `UntrustedData` security mode on in our MessagePack parser in 5.0. Previous versions use MessagePack 1.x which cannot set this value per-serialization and we are updating our documentation instead. In 5.0 we can do the better thing here and turn it on on the user's behalf.

We don't plan to have an option to disable this, but could consider it if there was customer need. It would definitely be *on-by-default*.

cc @blowdart
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[SignalR] Set "UntrustedData" security mode in MessagePackSerializerOptions" (#18717)

Issues.Title: [Discussion] Microsoft Security Advisory | MessagePack Denial of Service
Issues.Body: # Microsoft Security Advisory | MessagePack Denial of Service ## Executive summary *This advisory is being published in response to [CVE-2020-5234, a recent security advisory for the `MessagePack` NuGet package](https://github.com/neuecc/MessagePack-CSharp/security/advisories/GHSA-7q36-4xx7-xcxf). Since ASP.NET Core SignalR users may be using this package, we want to bring this issue to the attention of all ASP.NET Core users.* Microsoft is releasing this security advisory to provide information about a vulnerability that affects ASP.NET Core. This advisory also provides guidance on what developers can do to update their applications to remove this vulnerability. A denial of service vulnerability exists when using the [`MessagePack`](https://www.nuget.org/packages/MessagePack/) NuGet package. An attacker who successfully exploited this vulnerability could cause a denial of service against an ASP.NET Core application. The vulnerability can be exploited remotely, without authentication. A remote unauthenticated attacker could exploit this vulnerability by issuing specially crafted requests to the ASP.NET Core application. The update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how MessagePack handles deserialization. ## Discussion The original announcement can be found at https://github.com/aspnet/Announcements/issues/405 ## Mitigation factors Microsoft has not identified any mitigating factors for this vulnerability. ## How do I know if I am affected? If you have a runtime or SDK with a version listed in [affected software](#affected-runtime) or your application has a dependency on any of the packages listed in [affected packages](#affected-packages), you are exposed to the vulnerability. ### Affected software Any .NET Core 2.1, 3.0 or 3.1 application using SignalR with the MessagePack Hub Protocol. ### Affected packages Any ASP.NET Core-based application that uses any of the vulnerable packages shown below, or any ASP.NET Core application running on .NET Core 2.1.x, 3.0.0, 3.0.1 or 3.1.0. Package name | Vulnerable versions | Secure versions ------------ | ------------------- | ------------------------- MessagePack | 1.0.0 - 1.8.x | 1.9.3 *With code change described below* Microsoft.AspNetCore.SignalR.Protocols.MessagePack | 1.0.0 - 3.1.1 | *Update transitive reference to `MessagePack`* **NOTE:** MessagePack 2.x is *not compatible* with ASP.NET Core SignalR. ### How do I fix the issue? First examine the packages you have installed. If you have a vulnerable version of `MessagePack` in your package graph, you must update it. If you have a reference to `Microsoft.AspNetCore.SignalR.Protocols.MessagePack` in your project, you likely have a vulnerable version of `MessagePack` and should fix it by [directly referencing a secure version](#fixing-transitive-dependencies). **In addition to updating** you must set the `MessagePackSecurity.Active` static property to enable the `UntrustedData` mode for the MessagePack serializer, to ensure you are protected. See [the MessagePack advisory](https://github.com/neuecc/MessagePack-CSharp/security/advisories/GHSA-7q36-4xx7-xcxf) for details. Add the following code to the top of your app's entry point: ```csharp public static void Main(string[] args) { // Add the following lines // Enable additional security in MessagePack to handle untrusted data. MessagePackSecurity.Active = MessagePackSecurity.UntrustedData; // Continue with program initialization... } ``` If your application provides any custom `IMessagePackFormatter` implementations, you should also update them to include the relevant security measures by ensuring reads of variable-length values (such as strings) are done within a `using (MessagePackSecurity.DepthStep())` block. See [the MessagePack advisory](https://github.com/neuecc/MessagePack-CSharp/security/advisories/GHSA-7q36-4xx7-xcxf) for more details. ##### Direct dependencies Direct dependencies are discoverable by examining your `csproj` file. They can be fixed by [editing the project file](#fixing-direct-dependencies) or using NuGet to update the dependency. ##### Transitive dependencies Transitive dependencies occur when you add a package to your project that in turn relies on another package. For example, if Contoso publishes a package `Contoso.Utility` that, in turn, depends on `Contoso.Internals` and you add the `Contoso.Utility` package to your project now your project has a direct dependency on `Contoso.Utility` and, because `Contoso.Utility` depends 'Contoso.Internals', your application gains a transitive dependency on the `Contoso.Internals` package. Transitive dependencies are reviewable in two ways: * In the Visual Studio Solution Explorer window, which supports searching. * By examining the `project.assets.json` file contained in the obj directory of your project for `csproj` based projects The `project.assets.json` files are the authoritative list of all packages used by your project, containing both direct and transitive dependencies. There are two ways to view transitive dependencies. You can either [use Visual Studios Solution Explorer](#vs-solution-explorer), or you can review [the `project.assets.json` file](#project-assets-json)). ###### Using Visual Studio Solution Explorer To use Solution Explorer, open the project in Visual Studio, and then press Ctrl+; to activate the search in Solution Explorer. Search for the [vulnerable package](#affected-software) and make a note of the version numbers of any results you find. For example, searching for `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Core` in an example project that contains a package that takes a dependency on `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc` shows the following results in Visual Studio 2017: ![Screenshot of search results in Visual Studio 2017](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/796298/25858816/8ecdc2b4-3491-11e7-9363-746804bb9832.png) The search results appear as a tree. In the previous results, you can see that a reference to `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Core` version 1.1.2 is discovered. Under the Dependencies node is a NuGet node. Under the NuGet node is the list of packages you have directly taken a dependency on and their versions. In screenshot, the application takes a direct dependency on `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc`. `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc` in turn has leaf nodes that list its dependencies and their versions. The `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc` package takes a dependency on a version of `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.ApiExplorer`, that in turn takes a dependency on a version of `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Core`. ###### Manually reviewing project.assets.json Open the *project.assets.json* file from your projects obj directory in your editor. We suggest you use an editor that understands JSON and allows you to collapse and expand nodes to review this file. Visual Studio and Visual Studio Code provide JSON-friendly editing. Search the *project.assets.json* file for the [vulnerable package](#affected-software), using the format `packagename/` for each of the package names from the preceding table. If you find the assembly name in your search: v * Examine the line on which they are found, the version number is after the `/`. * Compare to the [vulnerable versions table](#affected-software). For example, a search result that shows `System.IO.Pipelines/4.5.0` is a reference to version 4.5.0 of `System.IO.Pipelines`. If your *project.assets.json* file includes references to the [vulnerable package](#affected-software), then you need to fix the transitive dependencies. If you have not found any reference to any vulnerable packages, this means either * None of your direct dependencies depend on any vulnerable packages, or * You have already fixed the problem by updating the direct dependencies. ##### Fixing Dependencies ###### Fixing direct dependencies Open *projectname.csproj* in your editor. If you're using Visual Studio, right-click the project and choose **Edit projectname.csproj** from the context menu, where projectname is the name of your project. Look for `PackageReference` elements. The following shows an example project file: ```xml netcoreapp2.1 ``` The preceding example has a reference to the [vulnerable package](#affected-software), as seen by the single `PackageReference` element. The name of the package is in the `Include` attribute. The package version number is in the `Version` attribute. The previous example shows a single direct dependency on `MessagePack` version 1.8.80 To update the version to the secure package, change the version number to the updated package version as listed on the table [previously](#affected-software). In this example, update `MessagePack` to the appropriate [fixed package number](#affected-software) for your major version. Save the *csproj* file. The example *csproj* now looks as follows: ```xml netcoreapp2.1 ``` If you're using Visual Studio and you save your updated *csproj* file, Visual Studio will restore the new package version. You can see the restore results by opening the **Output** window (Ctrl+Alt+O) and changing the **Show output from** drop-down list to **Package Manager**. If you're not using Visual Studio, open a command line and change to your project directory. Execute the `dotnet restore` command to restore the updated dependencies. Now recompile your application. If after recompilation you see a *Dependency conflict warning*, you must update your other direct dependencies to versions that take a dependency on the updated package. ###### Fixing transitive dependencies If your transitive dependency review found references to the [vulnerable package](#affected-software), you must add a direct dependency to the updated package to your *csproj* file to override the transitive dependency. Open *projectname.csproj* in your editor. If you're using Visual Studio, right-click the project and choose **Edit projectname.csproj** from the context menu, where projectname is the name of your project. Look for `PackageReference` nodes, for example: ```xml netcoreapp3.1 ``` You must add a direct dependency to the updated version of the [vulnerable package](#affected-software) by adding it to the *csproj* file. You do this by adding a new line to the dependencies section, referencing the fixed version. For example, if your search showed a transitive reference to a vulnerable `MessagePack` version, you'd add a reference to the [fixed package number](#affected-software). ```xml netcoreapp3.1 ``` After you've added the direct dependency reference, save your *csproj* file. If you're using Visual Studio, save your updated *csproj* file and Visual Studio will restore the new package versions. You can see the restore results by opening the **Output** window (Ctrl+Alt+O) and changing the **Show output from** drop-down list to **Package Manager**. If you're not using Visual Studio, open a command line and change to your project directory. Execute the `dotnet restore` command to restore the new dependencies. Finally, you must rebuild your application, test, and redeploy. ## Other Information ### Reporting Security Issues If you have found a potential security issue in .NET Core, please email details to secure@microsoft.com. Reports may qualify for the .NET Core Bug Bounty. Issues.Title: The non-scaffolded razor page "Register" does not recognise Password.RequiredLength.
Issues.Body:
### Describe the bug
Setting password length through 
```
public void ConfigureServices(IServiceCollection services){
  ...
  services.Configure<IdentityOptions>(options =>
  {
    options.Password.RequiredLength = 1;
  });
  ...
```
does not change the non-scaffolded razor page as it always says "The Password must be at least 6 and at max 100 characters long." if inputed password is < 6 characters.

### To Reproduce
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Create a new ASP.NET Core Web 2.1 application
2. Select "Web application (Model-View Controller)" 
3. Select "Change authentication"
3.1. Select "Individual User Account"
4. Select Ok to have the project scaffolded.
5. Open file Startup.cs
6. Add 
```
services.Configure<IdentityOptions>(options =>
{
  options.Password.RequiredLength = 1;
});
```
to method `ConfigureServices`.
7. Press F5 (or select your favourite start-debug method).
8. In the web browser that pops up
8.1. Select Register
8.2. Type "a@example.com" as user name (or select your favourite fast-to-type email addresss).
8.3. Type "a" as password (or any password shorter than 6 characters).
8.4. Select Register

### Expected behavior
The web page should have been updated with information about successful creation of user.

### Actual behaviour
The web page says "The Password must be at least 6 and at max 100 characters long."

### Additional context
I have a question at stack overflow https://stackoverflow.com/questions/53620708/how-do-i-set-password-options-in-aspnet-core-2-1 that explains the same issue if this is not clear enough.

This issue might be duplicate of #774.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "The non-scaffolded razor page "Register" does not recognise Password.RequiredLength." (#2091)

Issues.Title: Remember me isPersistent understanding
Issues.Body:
This is more of a question but its not enough of a question that i could post it up on stack overflow without risking it just getting closed as primary opinion based or to broad.   So i am going to put it here in hopes of getting an answer.

The issue is the understanding of how remember me is supposed to work.    My problem is that its not doing what we would expect it to do.   

Management expects when a user logs in and clicks remember me that they will then not be required to type their login and password again for a month.  Whether or not they will still have to type in the 2fa code is up for debate.

What is actually happening is that i can close the browser reboot and come back for about an hour and 15 minutes and then i will be forced to type my password again.    This still happens even with a valid `.AspNetCore.Identity.Application` cookie set that is not due to expire for another month.

After digging around in the code i found that Remember me is actually isPersistent and it is defined as.

>Flag indicating whether the sign-in cookie should persist after the browser is closed.

Which brings you to:

There are two different types of Cookies:

- session cookies, held in memory, and which expire once the browser exits
- persistent cookies, which have a time-to-live, are persisted on disk, and are sent by the browser until their time-to-live has elapsed.

All this being said remember machine 2fa works as expected i am not prompted again for the 2fa and i have a cookie on my machine `Identity.TwoFactorRememberMe`.

So I guess my question is why are we not getting a `Identity.FactorRememberMe` or why isn't sign in respecting a long life time of the `AspNetCore.Identity.Application` cookie?

How is this supposed to work exactly?   I am following the code here even though we have normal MVC and not razor pages like you have in the example.  I am still just calling 

>var signInUserResult = await _signInManager.PasswordSignInAsync(userName, password, rememberMe, true);

Note: I am using Asp .net Identity in Identity server 4 application.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Remember me isPersistent understanding" (#2079)

Issues.Title: Login doesn't show registered social logins after error
Issues.Body:
I'm using ASPNET Core 2.1 with Razor Pages UI Library and noticed that whilst registered social logins appear when I open the Login page, they disappear after an error like incorrect password.

There seems to be a bug in Identity\Pages\Account\Login.cshtml.cs as 
````
 public IList<AuthenticationScheme> ExternalLogins { get; set; }

````
is only initialised in OnGetAsync(), but if an error happens OnPostAsync() then Page() is returned so OnGetAsyn() doesn't get called. Changing error handling in  OnPostAsync() so RedirectToPage() is returned seems to fix the problem.

Please confirm this is a bug and comment on my fix
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Login doesn't show registered social logins after error" (#2074)

Issues.Title: Should IdentityUser be in the EntityFramework namespace?
Issues.Body:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/microsoft.aspnetcore.identity.entityframeworkcore.identityuser?view=aspnetcore-1.1

I'm looking through various implementations from the [readme](https://github.com/aspnet/Identity/blob/master/README.md) and I've noticed they all use `IdentityUser ` for their concrete type to pass to `UserManager`, or have had to craft a custom type to be able to have a contract between the database and the .NET AspNetIdentity implentation they've written (see the DynamoDB library).

I've had to do this too for the [Marten implementation I've written](https://github.com/yetanotherchris/Marten.AspNetIdentity), and the reason is, a `TUser` that your `UserStore` takes, should really be an interface - it will always have an email, most likely an Id of some sort, firstname, lastname and then a bag of properties.

Things become even more abstract when dealing with claims.

If everyone is using `IdentityUser` or their own custom `TUser` doesn't this defeat the purpose of AspnetIdentity - which is to be able to switch and change implementations easily? That isn't possible if your consumer is tightly coupled with a `TUser` implementation of the library.

### Example `TUser` implementations

- [MongoIdentityUser](https://github.com/tugberkugurlu/AspNetCore.Identity.MongoDB/blob/master/src/AspNetCore.Identity.MongoDB/MongoIdentityUser.cs)
- [DynamoIdentityUser](https://github.com/miltador/AspNetCore.Identity.DynamoDB/blob/master/src/AspNetCore.Identity.DynamoDB/DynamoIdentityUser.cs)
- [Redis uses `IdentityUser<string>`](https://github.com/aguacongas/Identity.Redis/blob/develop/src/Aguacongas.Identity.Redis/UserStore.cs)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Should IdentityUser be in the EntityFramework namespace?" (#2056)

Issues.Title: [Question] Passwords should not be of type String ?
Issues.Body:
My security team escalated to me that the `PasswordHasher` is vulnerable to heap inspection, as the password is of type `String`. 
It should be instead a byte array / span of bytes cleared at the end of the process, as it is done by any cryptographic operation in corefx. CC @bartonjs.
Same problem with any password related types (`IPasswordValidator`, and maybe also the `IUserPasswordStore`)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Question] Passwords should not be of type String ?" (#2051)

Issues.Title: Cannot start a webapi on specific SSL port managed by IISExpress
Issues.Body:
A brand new netcore webapi 2.2 is created. 

Current launch settings:
```
{
  "$schema": "http://json.schemastore.org/launchsettings.json",
  "iisSettings": {
    "windowsAuthentication": false,
    "anonymousAuthentication": true,
    "iisExpress": {
      "applicationUrl": "http://localhost:62813",
      "sslPort": 44396
    }
  },
```

After setting the SSL port to anything such as 11000, application won't get started on IIS Express, but the same app runs correctly on port 11000 after being published to local IIS (https://localhost:11000).

The only way to start it on IIS Express is to keep 443 prefix (i.e. 44300, 44301, etc). 

Is this restriction by design as stated [here](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/39430/changing-port-number-in-a-web-project-does-not-imm.html?childToView=43139#comment-43139)?

"You can change that value to whatever you want." definitely is not working as stated here: https://github.com/aspnet/Tooling/issues/286

Issues.Title: System.Collections.Immutable dll being replace by Microsoft.Net.Compilers
Issues.Body:
I have referenced `system.collections.immutable.dll` from the nuget package and I also have the nuget package installed for `Microsoft.Net.Compilers`. Everything works fine in my local but when I push my code to bamboo, in the runtime I get `Could not load file or assembly 'System.Collections.Immutable, Version=1.2.3.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b03f5f7f11d50a3a' or one of its dependencies. The located assembly's manifest definition does not match the assembly reference. (Exception from HRESULT: 0x80131040)`

When I checked logs on bamboo when it generates the artifacts, I can see that initially it copied the correct dll here:

`build    04-Apr-2019 03:20:33      Copying file from "E:\agt01\ENS-EB580-JOB1\Bin\Packages\System.Collections.Immutable.1.5.0\lib\netstandard1.0\System.Collections.Immutable.dll" to "E:\agt01\ENS-EB580-JOB1\Binaries\Release\\temp\Web\_PublishedWebsites\MyService\bin\System.Collections.Immutable.dll"`.

but then at some point, it replaced this dll with this: `build    04-Apr-2019 03:20:33      Copying file from "E:\agt01\ENS-EB580-JOB1\Bin\Packages\Microsoft.Net.Compilers.1.0.0\tools\System.Collections.Immutable.dll" to "E:\agt01\ENS-EB580-JOB1\Binaries\Release\\temp\Web\_PublishedWebsites\MyService\bin\System.Collections.Immutable.dll".`

How can I make sure that bamboo does not replace this dll and just uses it from the nuget package installed?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "System.Collections.Immutable dll being replace by Microsoft.Net.Compilers" (#1086)

Issues.Title: web deploy on windows 10
Issues.Body:
Hello,

can i publish my code by using web deploy to windows 10 machine.

i have setup my testing windows 10 machine for deployment, which is in local area network.

So i want to publish my code to that remote machine by using web deploy. can i do that ?

i have installed web deploy and also enabled web development remote service on windows 10 but i am not able to connect to remote machine using we deploy.

This returns me the following error every-time.
"ERROR_DESTINATION_NOT_REACHABLE"

interesting thing is i also have windows 10 on my machine & i am able to use web deploy on my local machine but it's not working with remote windows 10 machine.

is web deploy only meant for Windows servers not for other normal windows?

Thanks
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "web deploy on windows 10" (#1085)

Issues.Title: Feedback: ensure that .NET Core 1.0/1.1 tooling only supported in VS 2017 and won't be supported in VS 2019
Issues.Body:
Apologize if my feedback may sound controversial or may spark a debate.

I need to be sure that the problem mentioned on this [page](https://github.com/aspnet/Tooling/blob/master/known-issues-vs2017.md#to-create-aspnet-core-10--11-projects-install-visual-studios-net-core-10---11-developer-tools-for-web-component) about .NET Core 1.0/1.1 tooling is installed when creating new ASP.NET Core 1.0/1.1 project should not happen or should not be supported in VS 2019.

These are my main concerns:

1. VS 2019 is about to be released in around early 2019
2. ASP.NET Core 1.0/1.1 is not going to be supported anymore, based on [this page](https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/master/microsoft-support.md).
3. Creating new ASP.NET Core 1.0/1.1 will always install the .NET Core 1.0/1.1 web tooling, and this is not necessary when previous reason has reached the unsupported period and it's quite near or might be the same time of VS 2019 release.
4. Based on the problem mentioned above, VS 2017 has no "built in" tooling when creating new ASP.NET Core 1.0/1.1 project, but the external tooling may help. Therefore for those that still need to maintain ASP.NET Core 1.0/1.1 projects, we could use VS 2017 as long as the VS 2017 is still in support lifecycle or in mainstream support lifecycle.

I welcome feedback
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Feedback: ensure that .NET Core 1.0/1.1 tooling only supported in VS 2017 and won't be supported in VS 2019" (#1078)

Issues.Title: Support dotnet watch in launchSettings.json
Issues.Body:
I used to be able to use `dotnet watch` in Visual Studio by adding the following section to `launchSettings.json` and starting the project without debugging using CTRL + F5.

```
    "Kestrel (dotnet watch run)": {
      "commandName": "Executable",
      "executablePath": "C:\\Program Files\\dotnet\\dotnet.exe",
      "commandLineArgs": "watch run",
      "launchBrowser": true,
      "launchUrl": "https://localhost:5001/",
      "environmentVariables": {
        "ASPNETCORE_ENVIRONMENT": "Development"
      }
    },
```

This used to work in ASP.NET Core 1.1 but no longer does. According to https://github.com/aspnet/DotNetTools/issues/404 the new format for ASP.NET Core 2.0 is:

```
   "Kestrel (dotnet watch run)": {
      "commandName": "Executable",
      "executablePath": "C:\\Program Files\\dotnet\\dotnet.exe",
      "commandLineArgs": "watch run",
      "workingDirectory": "C:\\Users\\namc\\source\\repos\\WebApplication2\\WebApplication2",
      "launchBrowser": true,
      "launchUrl": "https://localhost:5001/",
      "environmentVariables": {
        "ASPNETCORE_ENVIRONMENT": "Development"
      }
    }
```

The problem with this is the hard coded `executablePath` which is Windows specific and the `workingDirectory` which is specific to wherever I did a Git clone on my local machine.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Support dotnet watch in launchSettings.json" (#1067)

Issues.Title: Nesting bug
Issues.Body:
The is a problem nesting embedded resources.  I was experimenting with nesting .cshtml files using the existing rules and did this:

Modal.cs (bootstrap modal web component)
   -> Modal.cs.cshtml (it's view file)

`Modal.cs.cshtml` is set to Embedded Resource, and clearly shows it, but is completed IGNORED by the build process (simply open the DLL in a text editor [such as Notepad++] and scroll to the bottom and look for text).  If I rename the file to "Modal.cshtml" instead it works perfectly fine!  :/  I don't think whether or not a file is embedded should have and role in excluding a file from being embedded so this seems like a bug to me.

Yes, I'm aware of upcoming nesting controls in v15.6, but I'm not able to install it yet, and regardless, this should work fine, so it should be looked into nonetheless.

Just to add: I'm using wild-cards to include the file.  If I explicitly add it I get this:

`Duplicate 'EmbeddedResource' items were included. ...`

So it's clearly found.  It's obviously something up with the build process not finding the nested file.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Nesting bug" (#1066)

Issues.Title: Microsoft Security Advisory | MessagePack Denial of Service
Issues.Body: # Microsoft Security Advisory | MessagePack Denial of Service ## Executive summary *This advisory is being published in response to [CVE-2020-5234, a recent security advisory for the `MessagePack` NuGet package](https://github.com/neuecc/MessagePack-CSharp/security/advisories/GHSA-7q36-4xx7-xcxf). Since ASP.NET Core SignalR users may be using this package, we want to bring this issue to the attention of all ASP.NET Core users.* Microsoft is releasing this security advisory to provide information about a vulnerability that affects ASP.NET Core. This advisory also provides guidance on what developers can do to update their applications to remove this vulnerability. A denial of service vulnerability exists when using the [`MessagePack`](https://www.nuget.org/packages/MessagePack/) NuGet package. An attacker who successfully exploited this vulnerability could cause a denial of service against an ASP.NET Core application. The vulnerability can be exploited remotely, without authentication. A remote unauthenticated attacker could exploit this vulnerability by issuing specially crafted requests to the ASP.NET Core application. The update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how MessagePack handles deserialization. ## Discussion Discussion for this issue can be found at https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/issues/18716 ## Mitigation factors Microsoft has not identified any mitigating factors for this vulnerability. ## How do I know if I am affected? If you have a runtime or SDK with a version listed in [affected software](#affected-runtime) or your application has a dependency on any of the packages listed in [affected packages](#affected-packages), you are exposed to the vulnerability. ### Affected software Any .NET Core 2.1, 3.0 or 3.1 application using SignalR with the MessagePack Hub Protocol. ### Affected packages Any ASP.NET Core-based application that uses any of the vulnerable packages shown below, or any ASP.NET Core application running on .NET Core 2.1.x, 3.0.0, 3.0.1 or 3.1.0. Package name | Vulnerable versions | Secure versions ------------ | ------------------- | ------------------------- MessagePack | 1.0.0 - 1.8.x | 1.9.3 *With code change described below* Microsoft.AspNetCore.SignalR.Protocols.MessagePack | 1.0.0 - 3.1.1 | *Update transitive reference to `MessagePack`* **NOTE:** MessagePack 2.x is *not compatible* with ASP.NET Core SignalR. ### How do I fix the issue? First examine the packages you have installed. If you have a vulnerable version of `MessagePack` in your package graph, you must update it. If you have a reference to `Microsoft.AspNetCore.SignalR.Protocols.MessagePack` in your project, you likely have a vulnerable version of `MessagePack` and should fix it by [directly referencing a secure version](#fixing-transitive-dependencies). **In addition to updating** you must set the `MessagePackSecurity.Active` static property to enable the `UntrustedData` mode for the MessagePack serializer, to ensure you are protected. See [the MessagePack advisory](https://github.com/neuecc/MessagePack-CSharp/security/advisories/GHSA-7q36-4xx7-xcxf) for details. Add the following code to the top of your app's entry point: ```csharp public static void Main(string[] args) { // Add the following lines // Enable additional security in MessagePack to handle untrusted data. MessagePackSecurity.Active = MessagePackSecurity.UntrustedData; // Continue with program initialization... } ``` If your application provides any custom `IMessagePackFormatter` implementations, you should also update them to include the relevant security measures by ensuring reads of variable-length values (such as strings) are done within a `using (MessagePackSecurity.DepthStep())` block. See [the MessagePack advisory](https://github.com/neuecc/MessagePack-CSharp/security/advisories/GHSA-7q36-4xx7-xcxf) for more details. ##### Direct dependencies Direct dependencies are discoverable by examining your `csproj` file. They can be fixed by [editing the project file](#fixing-direct-dependencies) or using NuGet to update the dependency. ##### Transitive dependencies Transitive dependencies occur when you add a package to your project that in turn relies on another package. For example, if Contoso publishes a package `Contoso.Utility` that, in turn, depends on `Contoso.Internals` and you add the `Contoso.Utility` package to your project now your project has a direct dependency on `Contoso.Utility` and, because `Contoso.Utility` depends 'Contoso.Internals', your application gains a transitive dependency on the `Contoso.Internals` package. Transitive dependencies are reviewable in two ways: * In the Visual Studio Solution Explorer window, which supports searching. * By examining the `project.assets.json` file contained in the obj directory of your project for `csproj` based projects The `project.assets.json` files are the authoritative list of all packages used by your project, containing both direct and transitive dependencies. There are two ways to view transitive dependencies. You can either [use Visual Studios Solution Explorer](#vs-solution-explorer), or you can review [the `project.assets.json` file](#project-assets-json)). ###### Using Visual Studio Solution Explorer To use Solution Explorer, open the project in Visual Studio, and then press Ctrl+; to activate the search in Solution Explorer. Search for the [vulnerable package](#affected-software) and make a note of the version numbers of any results you find. For example, searching for `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Core` in an example project that contains a package that takes a dependency on `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc` shows the following results in Visual Studio 2017: ![Screenshot of search results in Visual Studio 2017](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/796298/25858816/8ecdc2b4-3491-11e7-9363-746804bb9832.png) The search results appear as a tree. In the previous results, you can see that a reference to `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Core` version 1.1.2 is discovered. Under the Dependencies node is a NuGet node. Under the NuGet node is the list of packages you have directly taken a dependency on and their versions. In screenshot, the application takes a direct dependency on `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc`. `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc` in turn has leaf nodes that list its dependencies and their versions. The `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc` package takes a dependency on a version of `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.ApiExplorer`, that in turn takes a dependency on a version of `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Core`. ###### Manually reviewing project.assets.json Open the *project.assets.json* file from your projects obj directory in your editor. We suggest you use an editor that understands JSON and allows you to collapse and expand nodes to review this file. Visual Studio and Visual Studio Code provide JSON-friendly editing. Search the *project.assets.json* file for the [vulnerable package](#affected-software), using the format `packagename/` for each of the package names from the preceding table. If you find the assembly name in your search: v * Examine the line on which they are found, the version number is after the `/`. * Compare to the [vulnerable versions table](#affected-software). For example, a search result that shows `System.IO.Pipelines/4.5.0` is a reference to version 4.5.0 of `System.IO.Pipelines`. If your *project.assets.json* file includes references to the [vulnerable package](#affected-software), then you need to fix the transitive dependencies. If you have not found any reference to any vulnerable packages, this means either * None of your direct dependencies depend on any vulnerable packages, or * You have already fixed the problem by updating the direct dependencies. ##### Fixing Dependencies ###### Fixing direct dependencies Open *projectname.csproj* in your editor. If you're using Visual Studio, right-click the project and choose **Edit projectname.csproj** from the context menu, where projectname is the name of your project. Look for `PackageReference` elements. The following shows an example project file: ```xml netcoreapp2.1 ``` The preceding example has a reference to the [vulnerable package](#affected-software), as seen by the single `PackageReference` element. The name of the package is in the `Include` attribute. The package version number is in the `Version` attribute. The previous example shows a single direct dependency on `MessagePack` version 1.8.80 To update the version to the secure package, change the version number to the updated package version as listed on the table [previously](#affected-software). In this example, update `MessagePack` to the appropriate [fixed package number](#affected-software) for your major version. Save the *csproj* file. The example *csproj* now looks as follows: ```xml netcoreapp2.1 ``` If you're using Visual Studio and you save your updated *csproj* file, Visual Studio will restore the new package version. You can see the restore results by opening the **Output** window (Ctrl+Alt+O) and changing the **Show output from** drop-down list to **Package Manager**. If you're not using Visual Studio, open a command line and change to your project directory. Execute the `dotnet restore` command to restore the updated dependencies. Now recompile your application. If after recompilation you see a *Dependency conflict warning*, you must update your other direct dependencies to versions that take a dependency on the updated package. ###### Fixing transitive dependencies If your transitive dependency review found references to the [vulnerable package](#affected-software), you must add a direct dependency to the updated package to your *csproj* file to override the transitive dependency. Open *projectname.csproj* in your editor. If you're using Visual Studio, right-click the project and choose **Edit projectname.csproj** from the context menu, where projectname is the name of your project. Look for `PackageReference` nodes, for example: ```xml netcoreapp3.1 ``` You must add a direct dependency to the updated version of the [vulnerable package](#affected-software) by adding it to the *csproj* file. You do this by adding a new line to the dependencies section, referencing the fixed version. For example, if your search showed a transitive reference to a vulnerable `MessagePack` version, you'd add a reference to the [fixed package number](#affected-software). ```xml netcoreapp3.1 ``` After you've added the direct dependency reference, save your *csproj* file. If you're using Visual Studio, save your updated *csproj* file and Visual Studio will restore the new package versions. You can see the restore results by opening the **Output** window (Ctrl+Alt+O) and changing the **Show output from** drop-down list to **Package Manager**. If you're not using Visual Studio, open a command line and change to your project directory. Execute the `dotnet restore` command to restore the new dependencies. Finally, you must rebuild your application, test, and redeploy. ## Other Information ### Reporting Security Issues If you have found a potential security issue in .NET Core, please email details to secure@microsoft.com. Reports may qualify for the .NET Core Bug Bounty. Details of the .NET Core Bug Bounty including terms and conditions are at [https://aka.ms/corebounty](https://aka.ms/corebounty). ### Support You can ask questions about this issue on GitHub in the .NET Core GitHub organization. The main repos are located at https://github.com/dotnet/runtime and https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/. The Announcements repo (https://github.com/dotnet/Announcements) will contain this bulletin as an issue and will include a link to a discussion issue. You can ask questions in the linked discussion issue. ### Disclaimer The information provided in this advisory is provided "as is" without warranty of any kind. Microsoft disclaims all warranties, either express or implied, including the warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose. In no event shall Microsoft Corporation or its suppliers be liable for any damages whatsoever including direct, indirect, incidental, consequential, loss of business profits or special damages, even if Microsoft Corporation or its suppliers have been advised of the possibility of such damages. Some states do not allow the exclusion or limitation of liability for consequential or incidental damages so the foregoing limitation may not apply. ### Acknowledgments Yoshifumi Kawai from the MessagePack team. Levi Broderick and Andrew Arnott of Microsoft Corporation. ### External Links * [Security Advisory from the MessagePack package authors](https://github.com/neuecc/MessagePack-CSharp/security/advisories/GHSA-7q36-4xx7-xcxf) ### Revisions V1.0 (January 31, 2020): Advisory published. _Version 1.0_ _Last Updated 2020-01-31_

Issues.Title: ASP.NET Core SignalR MessagePack Hub Protocol moving to MessagePack v2.x package
Issues.Body:
## ASP.NET Core SignalR MessagePack Hub Protocol moving to MessagePack v2.x package

The ASP.NET Core SignalR MessagePack Hub Protocol uses the [`MessagePack`](https://www.nuget.org/packages/MessagePack) NuGet package for MessagePack serialization. In ASP.NET Core 5.0, we will move from the 1.x version to the latest 2.x version. This is a breaking change for:

* Anyone who is setting/configuring values on [`MessagePackHubProtocolOptions`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/microsoft.aspnetcore.signalr.messagepackhubprotocoloptions)
* Anyone who was using the MessagePack APIs directly **and** using the ASP.NET Core SignalR MessagePack Hub Protocol in the same application, as the newer version will be loaded instead of the previous version.

### Version introduced

5.0-preview1

### Old behavior

Previously, ASP.NET Core SignalR used the MessagePack 1.x package to serialize/deserialize MessagePack messages.

### New behavior

Now, ASP.NET Core SignalR will use the MessagePack 2.x package to serialize/deserialize MessagePack messages.

The new behavior will impact some aspects of message serialization and deserialization. See the [guidance for migrating from 1.x to 2.x](https://github.com/neuecc/MessagePack-CSharp/blob/master/doc/migration.md) published by the MessagePack package authors. Specifically, there are [behavioral changes to how DateTime values are serialized](https://github.com/neuecc/MessagePack-CSharp/blob/master/doc/migration.md#behavioral-changes).

### Reason for change

We believe updating to MessagePack v2.x will add useful new functionality and allow us to stay current with the latest improvements in that package.

### Recommended action

If you are using MessagePack directly in your application **and** using the SignalR MessagePack Hub Protocol, update your usage to adapt to any breaking changes in the 2.x release of MessagePack. The MessagePack package authors have published [guidance for migrating from 1.x to 2.x](https://github.com/neuecc/MessagePack-CSharp/blob/master/doc/migration.md).

### Category

ASP.NET

### Affected APIs

* [`Microsoft.AspNetCore.SignalR.MessagePackHubProtocolOptions`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/microsoft.aspnetcore.signalr.messagepackhubprotocoloptions)

To discuss this change, use the following issue: https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/issues/18692

---
#### Issue metadata

* Issue type: breaking-change
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ASP.NET Core SignalR MessagePack Hub Protocol moving to MessagePack v2.x package" (#404)

Issues.Title: Microsoft Security Advisory CVE-2020-0603 : ASP.NET Core Remote Code Execution Vulnerability
Issues.Body:
# Microsoft Security Advisory CVE-2020-0603 : ASP.NET Core Remote Code Execution Vulnerability ## Executive summary Microsoft is releasing this security advisory to provide information about a vulnerability in ASP.NET Core. This advisory also provides guidance on what developers can do to update their applications to remove this vulnerability. Microsoft is aware of a remote code execution vulnerability exists in ASP.NET Core software when the software fails to handle objects in memory. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could run arbitrary code in the context of the current user. A remote unauthenticated attacker could exploit this vulnerability by issuing specially crafted requests to the ASP.NET Core application. The update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how the ASP.NET Core web application handles objects in memory. ## Discussion Discussion for this issue can be found at https://github.com/dotnet/aspnetcore/issues/18337 ## Mitigation factors Microsoft has not identified any mitigating factors for this vulnerability. ## How do I know if I am affected? If you have a runtime or SDK with a version listed in [affected software](#affected-runtime) or your application has a dependency on any of the packages listed in [affected packages](#affected-packages), you are exposed to the vulnerability. ### Affected software Any .NET Core 2.1, 3.0 or 3.1 application using SignalR. ### Affected packages Any ASP.NET Core-based application that uses any of the vulnerable packages shown below, or any ASP.NET Core application running on .NET Core 2.1.x, 3.0.0, 3.0.1 or 3.1.0. Package name | Vulnerable versions | Secure versions ------------ | ------------------- | ------------------------- Microsoft.AspNetCore.Http.Connections | 1.0.0 - 1.0.4 | 1.0.15 Microsoft.AspNetCore.App | 2.1.0 - 2.1.14
3.0.0
3.1.0 | 2.1.15
3.0.1
3.1.1 Microsoft.AspNetCore.All | 2.1.0 - 2.1.14 | 2.1.15 ### How do I fix the issue? First examine the versions of .NET Core you have installed. You can list the versions you have installed by running the `dotnet --info` command. If you have multiple runtimes or SDKs installed, you must update all runtimes or SDKs separately. Once you've installed the updated runtime or SDK, restart your apps for the update to take effect. #### Applications targeting .NET Core runtime Update your runtime and SDKs to the versions listed in [Updated runtimes and SDKs](#fixed-runtime-sdks) then restart your application. #### Applications targeting .NET Framework First update your .NET Core runtimes and SDKs to the versions listed in [Updated runtimes and SDKs](#fixed-runtime-sdks). Some states do not allow the exclusion or limitation of liability for consequential or incidental damages so the foregoing limitation may not apply. ### Acknowledgments Brennan Conroy of Microsoft Corporation ### External Links [CVE-2020-0603](https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2020-0603) ### Revisions V1.0 (January 14, 2020): Advisory published. _Version 1.0_ _Last Updated 2020-01-14_
